moves.1. c4 Nf6: I don't like facing the English and usually encourage my opponent to convert into a King's Indian, where I'm much more familiar with the themes and tactics.  Perhaps I should learn the English properly.
moves.2. g3 g6 3. Bg2 Bg7 4. Nc3 O-O 5. Nf3 d6: White resists the temptation to play d4, clearly following his preconceived plan, as he raced through his moves.  I too was moving quickly but I was having to think and he had only used a minute!
moves.6... e5: Not sure this is best.  Perhaps I should have gone symmetrical with 6...c5.
moves.7. Bg5 Nbd7 8. Qc1: White was still moving instantaneously, which made me stop to ponder what he was planning and might have missed.  I decided to release my N from its pin, preparing a plan that was doomed to failure.
moves.8... Qe8 9. Bh6: Its job on g5 done, the B prepres to swap on g7
moves.9... Ng4: ? I think this was the start of my woes.  the N merely encourages White to do what he'd planned to do anyway and provides a target for White's attack.
moves.10. Bxg7 Kxg7 11. h3 Nh6: ?  This compounded the error.  The idea was to support the typical KID thrust of ...f5 but the N quickly becomes a liability here.  It would have been better to admit my folly immediately and return to f6.
moves.12. h4 f5: Consistent but merely weakening Black's defences further.
moves.13. h5: ! White prepares to expose the Nh6 to the full fury of his KR and Q.
moves.13... f4: ? Another consistent but useless move.  White's QN now has a choice of beautiful squares.
moves.14. gxf4: White opens up more attacking lines.
moves.14... exf4 15. Nd5: ! White forks f4 and c7, threatening a further fork from there, as well as taking closer order to Black's exposed King.
moves.15... Nc5: ? After my longest think of the game, I decided to counter-attack, hoping to fork White's K and Q by exploiting the pin on e2 but I'd overlooked the strength of my opponent's coming combination.
moves.16. Qc3+: ! I'd seen this but under-estimated it.
moves.16... Kg8: Nothing could usefully be interposed and 16...Kf7 just invited 17. Ng5+, when White's Ns looked horrible.
moves.17. hxg6: !  I'd seen this too but missed the most salient point of the position.
moves.17... Qxg6: ?? Just awful, though I was probably already lost anyway.  What was shocking was that, with so many threats around, I missed the biggest one.  A quick sense check of "What can White's Ns do?" should have stopped me from making this blunder.  Though what else I could have done that didn't lose quickly, I don't know.
moves.18. Ne7+: !  White applies the coup de grace, forking K and Q.  I'd had enough and resigned immediately.  Sorry to my teammates.
